newsitem.title: BELGIUM: GLUM RENAULT WORKERS MARCH THROUGH BRUSSELS.
newsitem.headline: GLUM RENAULT WORKERS MARCH THROUGH BRUSSELS.

text.p: Thousands of glum workers from Renault Belgium marched through Brussels on Monday to protest against plans by the Renault group to close their plant.

A crowd totalling 3,500 from Renault Belgium, reinforced by workers from other threatened factories, chanted "Renault Stays Open" and threw firecrackers as the demonstration passed riot police surrounding the main European Union institutions.
There were some scuffles and the windows of some nearby buildings were smashed. Belgian radio reported two cameramen had been set upon by the some of the crowd.
A delegation of workers later entered the offices of Belgium's national labour council for talks.

"Juppe - we want our pay", shouted protestors, addressing French Prime Minister Alain Juppe, who workers hope has influence over the Paris-based Renault in which the French state has a 46 percent stake.
Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene was due to discuss the Renault closure with Juppe on Monday.
"C4. Merci Louis," read one placard, referring to the form Belgians must complete to claim unemployment benefit and to Renault boss Louis Schweitzer.

The march was swelled by workers from the Belgian unit of Caterpillar , undergoing a restructuring, militant unionists from carmaker Volkswagen , and some of the several hundred employees facing the dole at steelmaker Clabecq.

Renault said last Thursday it would close its assembly plant in Vilvoorde near Brussels with the loss of 3,100 jobs as part of a reorganisation of production designed to save it 825 million French francs ($140 million) a year.

Luk Siebens, a 30-year-old single parent who had worked at Renault for the last 15 year, said he was resigned to losing his job. "I'm a realist, I think there's a five percent chance (of keeping it)", he told Reuters.

Production worker Bennie Van Noten, married with one child, said employees were clutching at straws, having occupied the plant, and organising more protests this week, which are to culminate in a national march for jobs next Sunday.
"There is a 90 percent chance Renault will not go back on its decision," he told Reuters, "the average age at Vilvoorde is 35, there is little chance we will find other jobs."
Workers said the main aim of the protests was to get the profitable, hi-tech plant reopened.
Union officials say they hold three trump cards in any negotiations with Renault chief executive officer Schweitzer.
They are holding 5,000 finished cars worth three billion Belgian francs hostage at the plant. The site also contains 10 billion francs of equipment and 2,000 semi-finished cars.
The occupied plant contains the moulds for the Megane Coupe D -- Vilvoorde is the only Renault site where the model is made.
Finally, the unions are waging a publicity war against Renault, hoping to dent its image as a socially-sensitive employer and thus affect car sales.
Unions are planning a day of protest action on Wednesday at Renault dealers around the country.
CEO Schweitzer is expected to come to Vilvoorde on Thursday to talk to Renault Belgium 's works council.
Belgian unions are counting on support from their Spanish and French colleagues, who they say have already agreed not to take on production quota moved abroad from Vilvoorde.

Meanwhile, French union fears of further job cuts in the Renault group were fired by a report in French newspaper Les Echos reported that Renault is expected to announce plans to cut about 3,000 jobs in France on top of the Belgian closure.
Renault had no comment on the report.
The Belgian government has condemned the decision as brutal and unacceptable but Renault's Schweitzer said on Saturday there is no chance the company will change its mind.
